questions.prompt: What is a computer programming language?

options.text: Instructions written by humans for computers to understand

feedback.short: Correct! Programming languages help us talk to computers.
feedback.detailed: Programming languages are like a bridge between humans and computers. They let us write instructions that computers can understand and follow!

options.text: Only 0s and 1s that computers read

feedback.short: Not quite! 0s and 1s are binary code, not programming languages.
feedback.detailed: Binary code (0s and 1s) is what computers understand deep down, but programming languages like Scratch make it easier for humans to write code without using just 0s and 1s!
feedback.socraticHint: Think about how Scratch blocks use words and pictures. Is that the same as just 0s and 1s?

options.text: A language that computers use to talk to each other

feedback.short: Not exactly! Programming languages help humans give instructions to computers.
feedback.detailed: Programming languages are made for humans to communicate with computers, not for computers to talk to each other. We use these languages to tell computers what to do!
feedback.socraticHint: Who creates the programs - humans or computers?

options.text: The language computers speak when they turn on

feedback.short: Not quite! Programming languages are tools we use to create programs.
feedback.detailed: Programming languages are tools that people use to write programs and tell computers what to do. They help us create games, apps, and websites!
feedback.socraticHint: Who writes programs using Scratch - you or the computer?

questions.correctAnswerText: Instructions written by humans for computers to understand

questions.prompt: Grace Hopper found a real moth in a computer. What do we call problems in code today?

options.text: Bugs

feedback.short: Correct! We call code problems 'bugs' because of Grace Hopper's moth!
feedback.detailed: When Grace Hopper found a real moth causing computer problems, she called it a 'bug'. Now we use the word 'bug' for any problem in our code!

options.text: Moths

feedback.short: Not quite! We use the word 'bugs' not 'moths'.
feedback.detailed: Even though Grace Hopper found a real moth, we call all code problems 'bugs' - not moths. The word 'bug' became the official term for any code mistake!
feedback.socraticHint: What word do programmers use when their code doesn't work right?

options.text: Errors

feedback.short: Close! 'Errors' is another word, but 'bugs' is the special term from Grace Hopper's story.
feedback.detailed: While 'error' is sometimes used, the word 'bug' came from Grace Hopper finding a real moth. This fun story gave us the term we use most often today!
feedback.socraticHint: What word comes from the moth that Grace Hopper found?

options.text: Glitches

feedback.short: Not quite! The special word from Grace Hopper's discovery is 'bugs'.
feedback.detailed: A 'glitch' is a different word. The moth that Grace Hopper found gave us the word 'bug' for code problems!
feedback.socraticHint: What insect did Grace Hopper find in the computer?

questions.correctAnswerText: Bugs

questions.prompt: You want to make a sprite in Scratch say 'Hello'. What do you need to add first?

options.text: An event block to start the action

feedback.short: Correct! Event blocks like the green flag start your code!
feedback.detailed: Great thinking! You always need an event block (like 'when green flag clicked') to tell Scratch when to start. Then you can add the 'say' block underneath!

options.text: Just the 'say' block by itself

feedback.short: Not quite! A 'say' block alone won't work - it needs an event block to start it.
feedback.detailed: The 'say' block needs an event block on top to tell it when to run. Think of the event block as the 'start' button!
feedback.socraticHint: How does Scratch know when to make your sprite say something?

options.text: A costume for the sprite

feedback.short: Not quite! Costumes change how sprites look, but don't make them say things.
feedback.detailed: While costumes are fun, you need code blocks to make your sprite say something. Start with an event block, then add a 'say' block!
feedback.socraticHint: What tells your sprite WHEN to start talking?

options.text: A background for the stage

feedback.short: Not quite! Backgrounds don't make sprites talk - you need code blocks!
feedback.detailed: Backgrounds make your project look nice, but to make a sprite say something, you need an event block to start and a 'say' block to make it talk!
feedback.socraticHint: What kind of blocks do you snap together to make things happen?

questions.correctAnswerText: An event block to start the action

questions.prompt: What happens when you click the green flag in Scratch?

options.text: All code blocks with 'when green flag clicked' start running

feedback.short: Correct! The green flag starts all your 'when green flag clicked' code!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When you click the green flag, it triggers all the code that starts with the 'when green flag clicked' block. It's like pressing the play button on a game!

options.text: Only the first sprite's code runs

feedback.short: Not quite! The green flag runs code for ALL sprites, not just the first one.
feedback.detailed: The green flag starts every piece of code that has the 'when green flag clicked' block, no matter which sprite it belongs to!
feedback.socraticHint: If you have three sprites all with 'when green flag clicked' blocks, what happens to each one?

options.text: It saves your project

feedback.short: Not quite! The green flag runs your code, it doesn't save it.
feedback.detailed: The green flag is for running your project, not saving it. To save, you need to use the File menu!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens to your sprites when you click the green flag?

options.text: It deletes all your sprites

feedback.short: No! The green flag is safe - it just runs your code!
feedback.detailed: Don't worry! The green flag never deletes anything. It just starts your program running. Your sprites are safe!
feedback.socraticHint: Is the green flag for running your project or changing it?

questions.correctAnswerText: All code blocks with 'when green flag clicked' start running

questions.prompt: Why is Scratch a good programming language for beginners?

options.text: It uses colorful blocks that snap together instead of typing code

feedback.short: Correct! Scratch blocks make coding visual and fun!
feedback.detailed: You're right! Scratch uses blocks that you can see and drag around. This makes it easier to learn coding without worrying about typing mistakes!

options.text: It's only for making simple projects

feedback.short: Not true! Scratch can make complex games and animations too!
feedback.detailed: Scratch might seem simple, but you can create amazing complex games, stories, and animations! Many professional concepts can be learned in Scratch.
feedback.socraticHint: Have you seen complex Scratch games? What makes them complex?

options.text: It writes the code for you automatically

feedback.short: Not quite! You still create all the code yourself by arranging blocks.
feedback.detailed: Scratch doesn't write code for you - you're the programmer! You choose which blocks to use and how to arrange them. Scratch just makes it easier by using blocks instead of typing.
feedback.socraticHint: Who decides what blocks to use and where to put them?

options.text: It doesn't teach real programming concepts

feedback.short: Not true! Scratch teaches the same concepts used in all programming!
feedback.detailed: Scratch teaches real programming concepts like loops, variables, and conditionals - the same ideas used in professional programming languages!
feedback.socraticHint: Do professional programmers use loops, variables, and conditionals too?

questions.correctAnswerText: It uses colorful blocks that snap together instead of typing code

questions.prompt: What is decomposition in computational thinking?

options.text: Breaking a big problem into smaller, easier pieces

feedback.short: Correct! Decomposition means breaking things into smaller parts!
feedback.detailed: Great job! Decomposition is like taking a huge LEGO set and building it one small section at a time. It makes big problems much easier to solve!

options.text: Making something break or fall apart

feedback.short: Not quite! Decomposition in coding means organizing, not breaking things.
feedback.detailed: In computational thinking, decomposition doesn't mean destroying something. It means carefully breaking a problem into parts so we can solve each part step by step!
feedback.socraticHint: When you plan how to build something complex, do you think about all the small parts first?

options.text: Finding patterns that repeat

feedback.short: Not quite! That's pattern recognition, not decomposition.
feedback.detailed: Finding patterns is called pattern recognition - another part of computational thinking! Decomposition is specifically about breaking problems into smaller pieces.
feedback.socraticHint: Which computational thinking concept is about dividing a big task into smaller tasks?

options.text: Writing step-by-step instructions

feedback.short: Not quite! That's creating algorithms, not decomposition.
feedback.detailed: Step-by-step instructions are called algorithms! Decomposition is about breaking big problems into smaller ones first, before we write the steps.
feedback.socraticHint: What do we call it when we divide one big problem into many small problems?

questions.correctAnswerText: Breaking a big problem into smaller, easier pieces

questions.prompt: You want to teach someone how to make a sandwich. Which computational thinking skill are you using when you list each step in order?

options.text: Algorithm

feedback.short: Correct! Step-by-step instructions are algorithms!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When you write clear steps like 'First get bread, then add filling, then put it together', you're creating an algorithm!

options.text: Abstraction

feedback.short: Not quite! Abstraction is about focusing on important details, not listing steps.
feedback.detailed: Abstraction is when you decide what's important and leave out extra details. Writing step-by-step instructions is creating an algorithm!
feedback.socraticHint: What do we call a list of steps that tells you exactly what to do?

options.text: Pattern recognition

feedback.short: Not quite! Pattern recognition is about finding things that repeat.
feedback.detailed: Pattern recognition is when you notice similarities or things that happen again and again. Creating a step-by-step plan is making an algorithm!
feedback.socraticHint: Are you finding patterns, or are you writing instructions?

options.text: Decomposition

feedback.short: Not quite! Decomposition is breaking problems into parts, not listing steps.
feedback.detailed: Decomposition would be if you broke 'make a sandwich' into smaller tasks first. Writing the actual steps in order is creating an algorithm!
feedback.socraticHint: What computational thinking concept involves writing clear steps?

questions.correctAnswerText: Algorithm

questions.prompt: When you decide to focus on studying for tomorrow's test instead of doing other homework, which computational thinking skill are you using?

options.text: Abstraction

feedback.short: Correct! Abstraction is focusing on what's most important!
feedback.detailed: You're right! Abstraction means focusing on the most important thing right now and setting aside other details for later. Great thinking!

options.text: Algorithm

feedback.short: Not quite! Algorithms are step-by-step instructions, not choosing what's important.
feedback.detailed: An algorithm is a list of steps to follow. When you decide what's most important to focus on, that's abstraction!
feedback.socraticHint: Are you making a list of steps, or deciding what matters most?

options.text: Decomposition

feedback.short: Not quite! Decomposition is breaking things into parts, not choosing priorities.
feedback.detailed: Decomposition is about dividing big problems into smaller ones. Choosing what's most important to focus on is abstraction!
feedback.socraticHint: Are you dividing a problem into parts, or deciding what needs your attention first?

options.text: Pattern recognition

feedback.short: Not quite! Pattern recognition is about finding similarities.
feedback.detailed: Pattern recognition is when you spot things that are similar or repeat. Deciding what's most important is abstraction!
feedback.socraticHint: Are you looking for patterns, or choosing what to focus on?

questions.correctAnswerText: Abstraction

questions.prompt: Look at this pattern: apple, banana, apple, banana, apple, ___. What comes next?

options.text: Banana

feedback.short: Correct! You recognized the pattern: apple, banana repeats!
feedback.detailed: Great job using pattern recognition! The pattern goes apple, banana, apple, banana, so banana comes next. You're thinking like a programmer!

options.text: Apple

feedback.short: Not quite! Look at the pattern carefully: apple, banana, apple, banana...
feedback.detailed: Take another look! The pattern alternates: apple, banana, apple, banana, apple. Since the last one is apple, what should come next?
feedback.socraticHint: If the pattern goes apple, banana, apple, banana, what follows banana each time?

options.text: Orange

feedback.short: Not quite! The pattern only uses apple and banana.
feedback.detailed: Orange isn't part of this pattern! The pattern repeats just two fruits: apple and banana. Look at how they alternate!
feedback.socraticHint: Which two fruits keep repeating in the pattern?

options.text: It could be any fruit

feedback.short: Not quite! Patterns follow rules - look for what repeats!
feedback.detailed: Patterns have specific rules! This pattern repeats apple, banana, apple, banana. When you recognize the pattern, you can predict what comes next!
feedback.socraticHint: Do you see the same two fruits repeating over and over?

questions.correctAnswerText: Banana

questions.prompt: Why is computational thinking useful in everyday life, not just in coding?

options.text: It helps you solve any problem by breaking it down and planning steps

feedback.short: Correct! Computational thinking helps solve all kinds of problems!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Whether you're planning a party, organizing your room, or creating a game, computational thinking helps you break problems into steps and find solutions!

options.text: It only works with computers and technology

feedback.short: Not true! Computational thinking works for solving any kind of problem.
feedback.detailed: Computational thinking started with computers, but the skills work for everything! You can use it to plan your day, cook a meal, or organize your backpack!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you break down a non-computer problem into smaller steps?

options.text: It makes computers think for you

feedback.short: Not quite! Computational thinking is how YOU think, not how computers think for you.
feedback.detailed: Computational thinking is a skill that helps YOU solve problems better. It's about how you think and plan, whether you're using a computer or not!
feedback.socraticHint: Who is doing the thinking when you use computational thinking - you or the computer?

options.text: It's too hard to use outside of class

feedback.short: Not true! You probably already use it without knowing it!
feedback.detailed: You use computational thinking all the time! When you plan how to get ready for school or figure out how to build something, you're already using these skills!
feedback.socraticHint: Have you ever broken a big task into smaller steps at home?

questions.correctAnswerText: It helps you solve any problem by breaking it down and planning steps

questions.prompt: What is an event in programming?

options.text: Something that happens that makes code start running

feedback.short: Correct! Events are triggers that start your code!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Events are like signals that tell your code to start. When you click the green flag or click a sprite, that's an event that makes things happen!

options.text: A block that moves sprites around

feedback.short: Not quite! Motion blocks move sprites, but events START the code.
feedback.detailed: Events are special blocks that start your code running. They don't move sprites - they tell Scratch WHEN to start doing things!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when you click the green flag - does it move a sprite or start your code?

options.text: A party that sprites have in your project

feedback.short: Not quite! Events in programming are triggers, not parties.
feedback.detailed: While 'event' can mean a party in real life, in programming an event is something that triggers your code to run - like clicking or pressing a key!
feedback.socraticHint: What does 'When green flag clicked' do in your code?

options.text: Any block in your code

feedback.short: Not quite! Events are special blocks that START code running.
feedback.detailed: Not all blocks are events! Event blocks are the special hat-shaped blocks that tell your code when to start, like 'when green flag clicked'.
feedback.socraticHint: Which blocks always go at the very top of your code to start it?

questions.correctAnswerText: Something that happens that makes code start running

questions.prompt: What shape are event blocks in Scratch?

options.text: Hat-shaped with a rounded top

feedback.short: Correct! Event blocks look like hats and go on top!
feedback.detailed: Great observation! Event blocks have a rounded top like a hat, which reminds us that they always go at the very top of our code!

options.text: Hexagon-shaped like stop signs

feedback.short: Not quite! Hexagon blocks are boolean blocks, not events.
feedback.detailed: Hexagon-shaped blocks are used for true/false questions. Event blocks are hat-shaped with a rounded top!
feedback.socraticHint: What shape is the 'when green flag clicked' block?

options.text: Rectangle-shaped like all other blocks

feedback.short: Not quite! Event blocks have a special rounded top.
feedback.detailed: Most blocks are rectangular, but event blocks are special! They have a rounded top like a hat so you know they start your code.
feedback.socraticHint: Look at the 'when green flag clicked' block - does the top look different from other blocks?

options.text: Round like circles

feedback.short: Not quite! Event blocks are hat-shaped, not circles.
feedback.detailed: Round blocks are reporter blocks that give you values. Event blocks have a special rounded top like a hat, but the whole block isn't circular!
feedback.socraticHint: What does the top of the 'when green flag clicked' block look like?

questions.correctAnswerText: Hat-shaped with a rounded top

questions.prompt: What is sequence in programming?

options.text: The order in which code blocks run, one after another

feedback.short: Correct! Sequence is all about the order of your code!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Sequence means your code blocks run in order from top to bottom, just like following recipe steps one at a time!

options.text: All code blocks running at the same time

feedback.short: Not quite! Sequence means one step after another, not all at once.
feedback.detailed: In sequence, code blocks run one at a time in order, not all together. It's like following directions step by step!
feedback.socraticHint: When you brush your teeth, do you do all the steps at once or one after another?

options.text: A type of event block

feedback.short: Not quite! Sequence is about order, not event blocks.
feedback.detailed: Sequence isn't a type of block - it's the concept of doing things in a specific order. Events start code, but sequence is how that code runs step by step!
feedback.socraticHint: Does sequence describe WHAT blocks you use or the ORDER you use them in?

options.text: Random blocks that run whenever

feedback.short: Not quite! Sequence is very organized, not random!
feedback.detailed: Sequence is the opposite of random! It means blocks run in a specific order, one after another, following your exact plan.
feedback.socraticHint: If you follow a recipe, do you do steps in order or randomly?

questions.correctAnswerText: The order in which code blocks run, one after another

questions.prompt:
Look at this code:
1. Say 'Hello'
2. Wait 1 second  
3. Say 'Goodbye'

What happens when this code runs?

options.text: The sprite says 'Hello', waits, then says 'Goodbye'

feedback.short: Correct! Code runs in sequence from top to bottom!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! You understand sequence! The blocks run in order: first 'Hello', then wait, then 'Goodbye'. Each step happens one after another!

options.text: The sprite says 'Goodbye', waits, then says 'Hello'

feedback.short: Not quite! Code runs from top to bottom, not bottom to top.
feedback.detailed: Remember, sequence means blocks run in order from top to bottom! So 'Hello' comes first, not 'Goodbye'.
feedback.socraticHint: Which block is at the top - 'Hello' or 'Goodbye'?

options.text: The sprite says both words at the same time

feedback.short: Not quite! Blocks run one at a time in sequence.
feedback.detailed: In sequence, each block runs one after another, not at the same time. The sprite will say 'Hello' first, then after waiting, say 'Goodbye'.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you say two different words at exactly the same time?

options.text: Nothing happens because the wait block stops everything

feedback.short: Not quite! The wait block pauses, then the code continues.
feedback.detailed: The wait block just makes the sprite pause for a moment. After waiting, the code continues to the next block! So 'Goodbye' will still appear.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens after you wait for something - do you stop forever or continue?

questions.correctAnswerText: The sprite says 'Hello', waits, then says 'Goodbye'

questions.prompt: Why is it important to put code blocks in the right order?

options.text: So your program does exactly what you want it to do

feedback.short: Correct! Order matters for your program to work right!
feedback.detailed: Great thinking! Just like putting on socks before shoes, code needs to run in the right order for your program to work the way you planned!

options.text: The computer won't run blocks in the wrong order

feedback.short: Not quite! The computer will run your blocks in ANY order you put them.
feedback.detailed: The computer follows your instructions exactly, even if they're in the wrong order! That's why YOU need to make sure they're in the right sequence.
feedback.socraticHint: If you tell someone to put on shoes before socks, will they do it even though it's wrong?

options.text: It doesn't matter, the computer figures it out

feedback.short: Not quite! Computers follow your exact instructions in order.
feedback.detailed: Computers can't think for themselves! They do exactly what you tell them in the exact order you tell them. You have to get the sequence right!
feedback.socraticHint: Can a computer guess what order you meant if you put blocks in the wrong order?

options.text: Only for making the code look neat and organized

feedback.short: Not quite! Order changes what actually happens, not just looks.
feedback.detailed: It's not just about looking nice! The order actually changes what your program does. Wrong order means wrong results!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens if you try to eat a sandwich before making it?

questions.correctAnswerText: So your program does exactly what you want it to do

questions.prompt: What is a loop in programming?

options.text: Code that repeats over and over again

feedback.short: Correct! Loops make code repeat!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Loops let us repeat code multiple times without writing it over and over. It's like telling your sprite to jump 10 times with just one block!

options.text: A circle shape in your code

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops repeat code, they're not about shapes.
feedback.detailed: While the word 'loop' can mean a circle shape, in programming it means repeating code over and over again!
feedback.socraticHint: What does the 'repeat 10' block do?

options.text: Code that only runs once

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops run multiple times, not just once.
feedback.detailed: Loops are all about repetition! They make code run many times, not just once. That's what makes them so useful!
feedback.socraticHint: What does 'repeat' mean?

options.text: An event that starts your program

feedback.short: Not quite! Events start code, loops repeat code.
feedback.detailed: Events (like the green flag) START your code. Loops REPEAT parts of your code over and over. They're different tools!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'repeat 10' start your code or repeat code?

questions.correctAnswerText: Code that repeats over and over again

questions.prompt: If you have a 'repeat 4' block with 'turn 90 degrees' inside, what happens?

options.text: The sprite turns 90 degrees four times (full circle)

feedback.short: Correct! The sprite does a complete 360-degree turn!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! The loop repeats 'turn 90 degrees' four times: 90 + 90 + 90 + 90 = 360 degrees, which is a full circle!

options.text: The sprite turns 90 degrees only once

feedback.short: Not quite! The 'repeat 4' makes it turn four times.
feedback.detailed: The 'repeat 4' block runs the code inside it 4 times, not just once! So the sprite turns 90 degrees four separate times.
feedback.socraticHint: What does the number in 'repeat 4' tell you?

options.text: The sprite turns 4 degrees

feedback.short: Not quite! The sprite turns 90 degrees each time, repeated 4 times.
feedback.detailed: The number in the repeat block (4) tells you HOW MANY TIMES to repeat, not the number of degrees! It turns 90 degrees, four times.
feedback.socraticHint: What number is inside the 'turn' block, and what number is in the 'repeat' block?

options.text: The sprite turns forever without stopping

feedback.short: Not quite! 'Repeat 4' stops after 4 times.
feedback.detailed: A 'repeat 4' block runs exactly 4 times and then stops. The 'forever' block is what runs without stopping!
feedback.socraticHint: What's the difference between 'repeat 4' and 'forever'?

questions.correctAnswerText: The sprite turns 90 degrees four times (full circle)

questions.prompt: What does the 'forever' block do?

options.text: Keeps repeating the code inside until you stop the program

feedback.short: Correct! Forever loops run non-stop until you click the stop button!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! The 'forever' block creates a loop that keeps going and going until you click the stop button. Perfect for animations and games!

options.text: Repeats the code exactly 10 times

feedback.short: Not quite! Forever means it never stops, not just 10 times.
feedback.detailed: The 'forever' block doesn't have a set number - it keeps going until you stop it! If you want it to repeat exactly 10 times, use 'repeat 10'.
feedback.socraticHint: What does the word 'forever' mean?

options.text: Runs the code only one time

feedback.short: Not quite! Forever means it keeps repeating!
feedback.detailed: The 'forever' block is the opposite of running once - it repeats the code over and over without stopping!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'forever' mean 'one time' or 'many times'?

options.text: Saves your project permanently

feedback.short: Not quite! Forever loops repeat code, they don't save projects.
feedback.detailed: The 'forever' block is for repeating code inside your program. To save your project, you use the File menu!
feedback.socraticHint: Is 'forever' a loop block or a save button?

questions.correctAnswerText: Keeps repeating the code inside until you stop the program

questions.prompt: Why are loops useful in programming?

options.text: They save time by not making you write the same code many times

feedback.short: Correct! Loops make coding faster and easier!
feedback.detailed: Great thinking! Instead of dragging and dropping the same blocks 100 times, you can use a loop to repeat them automatically. Work smarter, not harder!

options.text: They make your code run faster on the computer

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops help YOU write code faster, not make it run faster.
feedback.detailed: Loops don't make the computer run faster - they help YOU write code more easily! Instead of typing the same thing 100 times, you write it once in a loop.
feedback.socraticHint: Who does a loop help more - you when writing code, or the computer when running it?

options.text: They are the only way to make sprites move

feedback.short: Not quite! You can move sprites without loops too.
feedback.detailed: You can move sprites with or without loops! Loops just make it easier if you want to repeat the same movement many times.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you make a sprite move with just a 'move 10 steps' block without a loop?

options.text: They add more sprites to your project

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops repeat code, they don't create sprites.
feedback.detailed: Loops make code repeat - they don't create new sprites! To add sprites, you use the sprite button at the bottom of Scratch.
feedback.socraticHint: What does repeating code have to do with creating new sprites?

questions.correctAnswerText: They save time by not making you write the same code many times

questions.prompt: You want to make a sprite say the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Which is better?

options.text: Use a 'repeat 5' loop with a variable that counts up

feedback.short: Correct! A loop with a counting variable is the smart way!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Using a loop with a variable that increases is the professional way to count. Your code is shorter and easier to change!

options.text: Use five separate 'say' blocks: say 1, say 2, say 3, say 4, say 5

feedback.short: This works, but a loop is better! Less code means less work.
feedback.detailed: While five 'say' blocks would work, it's not the best way! If you needed to count to 100, would you want to add 100 blocks? A loop makes it much easier!
feedback.socraticHint: What if you wanted to count to 100? Would you want to add 100 blocks?

options.text: Use a 'forever' loop

feedback.short: Not quite! Forever would count forever, not just to 5.
feedback.detailed: A 'forever' loop wouldn't stop at 5 - it would keep counting forever! You need 'repeat 5' to stop after counting to 5.
feedback.socraticHint: Do you want to count forever or just to 5?

options.text: You can't make a sprite count in Scratch

feedback.short: Not true! Scratch can definitely count using loops and variables.
feedback.detailed: Scratch is great at counting! You can use loops and variables together to make your sprite count, do math, keep score, and much more!
feedback.socraticHint: Have you seen games that keep score? How do they count points?

questions.correctAnswerText: Use a 'repeat 5' loop with a variable that counts up

questions.prompt: What does a conditional (IF-THEN-ELSE) do?

options.text: Lets your program make decisions based on conditions

feedback.short: Correct! Conditionals help programs choose what to do!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Conditionals are like asking a question: IF it's raining, THEN bring an umbrella, ELSE leave it home. Your program can decide what to do!

options.text: Makes code repeat over and over

feedback.short: Not quite! That's what loops do. Conditionals make choices!
feedback.detailed: Loops repeat code, but conditionals help your program choose between different paths. Think: IF touching edge THEN bounce, ELSE keep moving.
feedback.socraticHint: What's the difference between repeating something and choosing between two options?

options.text: Runs all the code inside no matter what

feedback.short: Not quite! Conditionals choose which code to run.
feedback.detailed: Conditionals don't run everything! They check a condition and run EITHER the THEN part OR the ELSE part, not both!
feedback.socraticHint: If it's sunny, do you bring an umbrella AND sunglasses, or do you choose?

options.text: Stops your program completely

feedback.short: Not quite! Conditionals help programs make choices, not stop.
feedback.detailed: Conditionals don't stop your program - they help it make smart decisions about what to do next!
feedback.socraticHint: When you ask 'IF I'm hungry, THEN eat', does that stop everything or help you decide?

questions.correctAnswerText: Lets your program make decisions based on conditions

questions.prompt: Look at this code: IF touching edge THEN turn right. What happens when the sprite touches the edge?

options.text: The sprite turns right

feedback.short: Correct! When the IF condition is true, the THEN action happens!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! The sprite checks: Am I touching the edge? Yes! Then it does the THEN part: turn right. Great understanding of conditionals!

options.text: The sprite keeps moving straight

feedback.short: Not quite! When touching the edge, the condition is TRUE so it turns.
feedback.detailed: When the sprite touches the edge, the IF condition becomes true, so it does what the THEN says: turn right!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when the condition after IF is true?

options.text: The sprite disappears

feedback.short: Not quite! The code says to turn right, not disappear.
feedback.detailed: Look at what comes after THEN - it says 'turn right', not hide or disappear! The sprite will turn when it touches the edge.
feedback.socraticHint: What action is written after the THEN?

options.text: Nothing happens

feedback.short: Not quite! When the IF is true, the THEN action runs!
feedback.detailed: Something definitely happens! When touching edge (condition is true), the sprite turns right (the THEN action).
feedback.socraticHint: If the condition is true, does the code after THEN run or not?

questions.correctAnswerText: The sprite turns right

questions.prompt: What is an operator in programming?

options.text: A block that does math or compares things

feedback.short: Correct! Operators help us calculate and compare!
feedback.detailed: Great! Operators are like tools that help you do math (like + -  ) or compare things (like > < =). They're super useful in programs!

options.text: A person who runs the computer

feedback.short: Not quite! An operator in coding is a special block, not a person.
feedback.detailed: While 'operator' can mean a person in real life, in programming it's a type of block that does math or comparisons!
feedback.socraticHint: What do the + -   blocks do in Scratch?

options.text: A block that makes sprites move

feedback.short: Not quite! Motion blocks move sprites. Operators do math and comparisons.
feedback.detailed: Motion blocks move sprites, but operators help you calculate numbers and compare values! They're in the green Operators section.
feedback.socraticHint: Which Scratch blocks help you add, subtract, or compare numbers?

options.text: A type of event block

feedback.short: Not quite! Event blocks start code. Operators do math and comparisons.
feedback.detailed: Event blocks start your code running, but operators are different - they help you do math and compare things!
feedback.socraticHint: What color are the blocks that add and subtract numbers?

questions.correctAnswerText: A block that does math or compares things

questions.prompt: What does this condition check: IF score > 50 THEN say 'You win!'

options.text: If the score is greater than 50

feedback.short: Correct! The > symbol means 'greater than'!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! The > operator checks if the score is more than 50. If yes (like 51, 60, 100), the sprite says 'You win!'

options.text: If the score is less than 50

feedback.short: Not quite! The > symbol points to the smaller number, meaning 'greater than'.
feedback.detailed: The > symbol means 'greater than', not 'less than'. Think of it like a hungry alligator eating the bigger number! So score > 50 means score is bigger than 50.
feedback.socraticHint: Which way does the > symbol point - toward the bigger or smaller number?

options.text: If the score is exactly 50

feedback.short: Not quite! > means greater than, not equal to.
feedback.detailed: The > symbol means greater than, not equal to! If the score is exactly 50, this condition is false. For exactly 50, you'd use = instead.
feedback.socraticHint: Is 50 greater than 50, or equal to 50?

options.text: If the score is 50 or higher

feedback.short: Close! > means greater than (not equal to), so 51 or higher.
feedback.detailed: Good thinking, but > means strictly greater than (not including 50). You'd need >= to include 50. With just >, scores of 51, 52, 53... would work, but exactly 50 wouldn't!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'greater than 50' include the number 50 itself?

questions.correctAnswerText: If the score is greater than 50

questions.prompt: Why do we need IF-THEN-ELSE blocks in programs?

options.text: To make programs that can respond differently to different situations

feedback.short: Correct! Conditionals make programs smart and flexible!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Just like you make different choices (umbrella when raining, sunglasses when sunny), programs need conditionals to respond to different situations!

options.text: To make code repeat multiple times

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops make code repeat. Conditionals make choices!
feedback.detailed: If you want to repeat code, use loops like 'repeat' or 'forever'. Conditionals help your program choose between different actions!
feedback.socraticHint: What's the difference between doing something many times and choosing what to do?

options.text: To make programs run faster

feedback.short: Not quite! Conditionals make programs smarter, not faster.
feedback.detailed: Conditionals don't make programs run faster - they make programs able to decide what to do based on different conditions!
feedback.socraticHint: Do conditionals change speed or behavior?

options.text: Because every program must have them

feedback.short: Not quite! Simple programs can work without conditionals.
feedback.detailed: Not every program needs conditionals! Simple programs that always do the same thing don't need them. But conditionals make programs more interesting and interactive!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you make a simple 'say hello' program without any IF blocks?

questions.correctAnswerText: To make programs that can respond differently to different situations

questions.prompt: What is a variable?

options.text: A storage box that can hold one piece of information that can change

feedback.short: Correct! Variables are like memory boxes that can change!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! A variable is like a labeled box that holds one value. You can change what's inside anytime, just like switching drinks in a water bottle!

options.text: A number that never changes

feedback.short: Not quite! Variables can change - that's why they're called 'variable'!
feedback.detailed: The word 'variable' means it can vary (change)! If a number never changes, it's called a constant, not a variable.
feedback.socraticHint: What does 'vary' in 'variable' mean?

options.text: A block that makes sprites move

feedback.short: Not quite! Motion blocks move sprites. Variables store information.
feedback.detailed: Variables don't make things move - they store information like scores, names, or numbers that your program can remember and use!
feedback.socraticHint: What do you store in a labeled box?

options.text: A list of many different values

feedback.short: Not quite! That's a list. Variables hold ONE value at a time.
feedback.detailed: A variable can only hold ONE value at a time (like one number or one word). If you need to store many values, you'd use a list!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you put multiple drinks in one water bottle at the same time?

questions.correctAnswerText: A storage box that can hold one piece of information that can change

questions.prompt: You create a variable called 'score' and set it to 10. Then you change score to 20. What is the score now?

feedback.short: Correct! The new value replaces the old one!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When you change a variable, the new value (20) replaces the old value (10). The variable only remembers the most recent value!

feedback.short: Not quite! The score changed to 20, so the old value is gone.
feedback.detailed: When you set a variable to a new value, it forgets the old value! After changing to 20, the variable no longer remembers 10.
feedback.socraticHint: If you pour water out of a bottle and fill it with juice, what's in the bottle now?

feedback.short: Not quite! Changing a variable replaces the old value, it doesn't add.
feedback.detailed: When you 'set' a variable to 20, you replace the old value with 20 - you don't add them together. If you wanted to add, you'd use 'change score by 10'!
feedback.socraticHint: What's the difference between 'set to' and 'change by'?

options.text: Both 10 and 20

feedback.short: Not quite! A variable can only hold ONE value at a time.
feedback.detailed: A variable can only remember one value at a time! After you change it to 20, it forgets the 10. Think of it like a water bottle - it can only hold one drink at a time!
feedback.socraticHint: Can one labeled box hold two different values at the same time?

questions.prompt: Which data type is used for words and letters?

options.text: Text (or String)

feedback.short: Correct! Text or String is for words and letters!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Text (also called Strings) is the data type for letters, words, and sentences like 'Hello' or 'Game Over'!

options.text: Number

feedback.short: Not quite! Numbers are for counting and math, not letters.
feedback.detailed: Numbers are for things you can count and do math with (like 5, 10, 3.14). For words and letters, you need the Text or String data type!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you do math with the word 'Hello'?

options.text: Boolean

feedback.short: Not quite! Boolean is only for true or false, not words.
feedback.detailed: Boolean is special - it can only be 'true' or 'false'! For words and letters, you need Text (String) data type.
feedback.socraticHint: Can boolean hold the word 'Hello', or only true/false?

options.text: Variable

feedback.short: Not quite! Variable is the box, not the type of data inside.
feedback.detailed: A variable is like the box that holds data. The data TYPE describes what kind of thing is in the box (text, number, or boolean)!
feedback.socraticHint: Is 'variable' describing the box or what's inside the box?

questions.correctAnswerText: Text (or String)

questions.prompt: What is a Boolean data type?

options.text: A data type that can only be True or False

feedback.short: Correct! Boolean is always True or False!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Boolean is like a yes/no question - it can only be True (yes) or False (no). Nothing else! Great for making decisions in your code!

options.text: A data type for numbers

feedback.short: Not quite! Numbers are a different data type.
feedback.detailed: Numbers are their own data type! Boolean is special - it can ONLY be True or False, not numbers!
feedback.socraticHint: Can Boolean be the number 5, or only True/False?

options.text: A data type for words

feedback.short: Not quite! Words are Text/String. Boolean is only True or False.
feedback.detailed: Words and letters use the Text (String) data type. Boolean can ONLY be True or False - no words allowed!
feedback.socraticHint: Can Boolean hold the word 'maybe', or only True/False?

options.text: A hexagon-shaped block

feedback.short: Close! Hexagon blocks HOLD boolean values, but Boolean is the data type.
feedback.detailed: Good observation! Hexagon-shaped blocks do give you boolean values (True/False), but Boolean is the name of the data type, not the shape!
feedback.socraticHint: Is Boolean describing the shape of a block or the type of data?

questions.correctAnswerText: A data type that can only be True or False

questions.prompt: Why do we need variables in games?

options.text: To remember important information like score, lives, and level

feedback.short: Correct! Variables help games remember important information!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Variables are like the game's memory. They remember your score, how many lives you have, what level you're on, and much more!

options.text: To make sprites move faster

feedback.short: Not quite! Variables store information, they don't make things faster.
feedback.detailed: Variables don't make sprites move faster - they store information! You could use a variable to STORE a speed value, but the variable itself doesn't change speed.
feedback.socraticHint: Do variables make things move, or remember information?

options.text: To create new sprites

feedback.short: Not quite! Variables store information, they don't create sprites.
feedback.detailed: Variables don't create sprites - they store and remember information! To create sprites, you use the sprite button in Scratch.
feedback.socraticHint: What does a storage box do - create things or store things?

options.text: Games don't need variables

feedback.short: Not true! Almost all games use variables!
feedback.detailed: Games definitely need variables! How else would they keep track of your score, lives, time, level, and all the other important information?
feedback.socraticHint: How does a game remember your score if not with a variable?

questions.correctAnswerText: To remember important information like score, lives, and level

questions.prompt: What is a list in programming?

options.text: A container that can hold many values at the same time

feedback.short: Correct! Lists can hold multiple values together!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! A list is like a shopping list - it can hold many items all at once. Much better than making a separate variable for each item!

options.text: A variable that holds only one value

feedback.short: Not quite! That's a variable. Lists hold MANY values!
feedback.detailed: Variables hold one value, but lists are special - they can hold many values at once! That's what makes lists so powerful!
feedback.socraticHint: Can a shopping list have multiple items on it?

options.text: A type of loop

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops repeat code, lists store multiple values.
feedback.detailed: Loops make code repeat, but lists are for storing! Though you often use loops together with lists to go through all the items!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a list repeat actions or store items?

options.text: A way to organize your sprites

feedback.short: Not quite! Lists store data values, not sprites.
feedback.detailed: Lists store data like numbers, words, or scores - not sprites! They're for organizing information your program needs to remember.
feedback.socraticHint: What kind of information would you put on a shopping list?

questions.correctAnswerText: A container that can hold many values at the same time

questions.prompt: You have a list: ['apple', 'banana', 'orange']. What is at index 2?

options.text: banana

feedback.short: Correct! In Scratch, we count from 1, so index 2 is banana!
feedback.detailed: Great job! In Scratch lists, we start counting at 1. So index 1 = apple, index 2 = banana, index 3 = orange!

options.text: apple

feedback.short: Not quite! Apple is at index 1, not index 2.
feedback.detailed: In Scratch, we start counting from 1! Apple is first (index 1), so banana is at index 2.
feedback.socraticHint: If we start counting at 1, what number is the second item?

options.text: orange

feedback.short: Not quite! Orange is at index 3.
feedback.detailed: Orange is the third item! In Scratch, the first item is index 1, second is index 2, third is index 3. So banana is at index 2!
feedback.socraticHint: What position is orange in - second or third?

options.text: There is nothing at index 2

feedback.short: Not quite! Index 2 points to the second item: banana!
feedback.detailed: There definitely is something at index 2! In Scratch, we count starting from 1, so index 2 is the second item: banana!
feedback.socraticHint: How many items are in the list? Can you point to the second one?

questions.correctAnswerText: banana

questions.prompt: Why is using a list better than using many separate variables?

options.text: Lists keep related items organized together and are easier to manage

feedback.short: Correct! Lists are organized and easy to work with!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Instead of having variable1, variable2, variable3... you have one neat list! It's easier to add items, remove items, and keep everything organized!

options.text: Lists make your program run faster

feedback.short: Not quite! Lists help organize, not speed up programs.
feedback.detailed: Lists don't make programs run faster - they make YOUR work easier by organizing data! Instead of managing 100 variables, you manage one list!
feedback.socraticHint: Is a list about computer speed or programmer organization?

options.text: You can't use variables and lists together

feedback.short: Not true! You can use variables and lists together!
feedback.detailed: You can absolutely use both! Variables are great for single values, and lists are great for multiple related values. Use the right tool for each job!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you have both a shopping list AND a single 'total cost' variable?

options.text: Lists are not better, they are the same as variables

feedback.short: Not quite! Lists have a special advantage - they hold multiple values!
feedback.detailed: Lists are better for certain situations! When you need to store many related items (like high scores from 10 players), one list is much better than 10 variables!
feedback.socraticHint: Would you rather write 100 variable names or use one list?

questions.correctAnswerText: Lists keep related items organized together and are easier to manage

questions.prompt: What happens when you use the 'add [item] to [list]' block?

options.text: The item is added to the end of the list

feedback.short: Correct! New items go at the end of the list!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When you add an item to a list, it goes to the end, just like adding a new item to the bottom of your shopping list!

options.text: The item replaces everything in the list

feedback.short: Not quite! Adding keeps the old items and adds new ones!
feedback.detailed: The 'add' block doesn't delete anything - it adds to the list! All your old items stay, and the new item goes at the end.
feedback.socraticHint: When you add an item to a shopping list, do the old items disappear?

options.text: The item is added to the beginning of the list

feedback.short: Not quite! The 'add' block puts items at the END.
feedback.detailed: The 'add' block puts new items at the end of the list! If you want to add at the beginning, you'd use the 'insert at 1' block instead!
feedback.socraticHint: When you add something to the bottom of a list, is it at the start or the end?

options.text: Nothing happens to the list

feedback.short: Not quite! The list definitely changes when you add items!
feedback.detailed: The list definitely changes! After you add an item, your list has one more item in it at the end!
feedback.socraticHint: If you have 3 items and add 1 more, how many do you have now?

questions.correctAnswerText: The item is added to the end of the list

questions.prompt: When would you use a list in a game?

options.text: To store multiple high scores or player names

feedback.short: Correct! Lists are perfect for storing multiple related items!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Lists are great for storing things like all the high scores, all the player names, or all the items in your inventory. One list can hold them all!

options.text: To store just one player's score

feedback.short: Not quite! For one score, a variable is better than a list.
feedback.detailed: If you only need to store ONE score, a simple variable is better! Lists are great when you need to store MULTIPLE scores or items!
feedback.socraticHint: Do you need a whole shopping list for just one apple, or just remember 'apple'?

options.text: Lists don't work in games

feedback.short: Not true! Games use lists all the time!
feedback.detailed: Games use lists constantly! For high scores, inventory items, enemy positions, power-ups collected, and so much more!
feedback.socraticHint: How would a game remember the top 10 high scores without a list?

options.text: To make sprites move

feedback.short: Not quite! Lists store data, motion blocks move sprites.
feedback.detailed: Lists don't make sprites move - motion blocks do that! Lists store information your game needs to remember, like scores or items.
feedback.socraticHint: Does a shopping list make you move, or help you remember what to buy?

questions.correctAnswerText: To store multiple high scores or player names

questions.prompt: What is a function in programming?

options.text: A reusable group of code blocks that you can use over and over

feedback.short: Correct! Functions are reusable code recipes!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Functions are like creating your own special moves! You make them once, then use them whenever you need. It saves time and keeps code organized!

options.text: A variable that stores numbers

feedback.short: Not quite! Variables store data, functions are groups of code!
feedback.detailed: Variables store information, but functions are different - they're groups of code blocks that work together to do a task!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a function store information or perform actions?

options.text: A type of loop

feedback.short: Not quite! Loops repeat code, functions package code to reuse!
feedback.detailed: Loops make code repeat, but functions are different - they let you package code into a reusable block! Though functions can contain loops inside them!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a function repeat code automatically, or run when you call it?

options.text: A special type of sprite

feedback.short: Not quite! Functions are code blocks, not sprites!
feedback.detailed: Functions aren't sprites - they're custom blocks you create! In Scratch, you make them with 'Make a Block' in the My Blocks section!
feedback.socraticHint: Are functions characters on screen or code you can reuse?

questions.correctAnswerText: A reusable group of code blocks that you can use over and over

questions.prompt: In Scratch, what do you click to create a function?

options.text: Make a Block (in the My Blocks section)

feedback.short: Correct! 'Make a Block' creates your custom function!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! In Scratch, functions are called 'custom blocks' and you create them by clicking 'Make a Block' in the My Blocks category!

options.text: Make a Variable

feedback.short: Not quite! That makes variables, not functions!
feedback.detailed: 'Make a Variable' creates variables to store data. To create functions, you use 'Make a Block' in My Blocks!
feedback.socraticHint: What's the difference between storing data and creating reusable code?

options.text: Make a List

feedback.short: Not quite! That makes lists, not functions!
feedback.detailed: 'Make a List' creates lists to store multiple values. To create functions, you use 'Make a Block' in My Blocks!
feedback.socraticHint: Do lists store data or perform actions?

options.text: Add a new sprite

feedback.short: Not quite! That creates sprites, not functions!
feedback.detailed: Adding sprites creates characters for your project. To create functions, you use 'Make a Block' in My Blocks!
feedback.socraticHint: Are functions about creating characters or creating reusable code?

questions.correctAnswerText: Make a Block (in the My Blocks section)

questions.prompt: What is a parameter in a function?

options.text: A blank space where you can put different information each time you use the function

feedback.short: Correct! Parameters make functions flexible!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Parameters are like blank spaces in your function. You can fill them with different information each time, making your function work in different ways!

options.text: The name of your function

feedback.short: Not quite! The function has a name, but parameters are the inputs!
feedback.detailed: The function name is what you call it (like 'say hello'). Parameters are the blank spaces where you put different information each time!
feedback.socraticHint: Is 'hello' a name or an input you can change?

options.text: A type of loop

feedback.short: Not quite! Parameters are inputs to functions, not loops!
feedback.detailed: Loops repeat code, but parameters are something different - they're the blank spaces in functions where you can put different values!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a parameter repeat something or hold information?

options.text: A variable that never changes

feedback.short: Not quite! Parameters can have different values each time!
feedback.detailed: Parameters are the opposite of never changing! They're meant to be filled with DIFFERENT values each time you use the function!
feedback.socraticHint: If you say hello to different friends, does the name change or stay the same?

questions.correctAnswerText: A blank space where you can put different information each time you use the function

questions.prompt: You create a function 'greet [name]' that says 'Hello [name]!'. When you use greet 'Sam', what happens?

options.text: The sprite says 'Hello Sam!'

feedback.short: Correct! The parameter 'name' gets filled with 'Sam'!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When you call the function with 'Sam', the parameter [name] becomes 'Sam', so the sprite says 'Hello Sam!'. That's the power of parameters!

options.text: The sprite says 'Hello [name]!'

feedback.short: Not quite! The parameter gets replaced with the actual value 'Sam'.
feedback.detailed: The [name] parameter doesn't stay as [name] - it gets replaced with the actual value you give it! So it becomes 'Hello Sam!', not 'Hello [name]!'
feedback.socraticHint: When you fill in a blank with 'Sam', do you keep the word 'blank' or use 'Sam'?

options.text: Nothing happens

feedback.short: Not quite! The function runs and says hello!
feedback.detailed: When you use a function, it runs the code inside! So the sprite definitely says something - 'Hello Sam!'
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when you call a function?

options.text: The sprite says 'greet Sam'

feedback.short: Not quite! The function runs the code INSIDE it, not just says its name.
feedback.detailed: The function name is just how you call it. The actual code inside (say 'Hello [name]!') is what runs! So it says 'Hello Sam!', not 'greet Sam'.
feedback.socraticHint: Does a function say its name or run the code inside it?

questions.correctAnswerText: The sprite says 'Hello Sam!'

questions.prompt: Why are functions useful in programming?

options.text: They let you reuse code instead of writing the same thing many times

feedback.short: Correct! Functions save time and keep code organized!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! If you need the same code in 10 places, create a function once and use it 10 times! It saves time and makes your code cleaner and easier to fix!

options.text: They make programs run faster

feedback.short: Not quite! Functions help organize code, not speed it up.
feedback.detailed: Functions don't make the computer run faster - they help YOU code faster! Instead of writing the same 20 blocks multiple times, write them once in a function!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a function change computer speed or programmer efficiency?

options.text: They are the only way to make sprites do anything

feedback.short: Not true! You can make sprites do things without functions.
feedback.detailed: You can definitely code without functions! Functions are just a helpful tool for organizing and reusing code when you need the same actions multiple times.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you make a sprite move with just a 'move 10 steps' block?

options.text: They automatically write code for you

feedback.short: Not quite! YOU write the code inside functions.
feedback.detailed: Functions don't write code for you - YOU create them! You decide what code goes inside, then you can reuse that code easily!
feedback.socraticHint: Who writes the code that goes inside a function - you or the computer?

questions.correctAnswerText: They let you reuse code instead of writing the same thing many times
